epjyd6m0"><p class="css-aknsld e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/by/david-yaffe-bellany" class="css-mrorfa e1jsehar0">David Yaffe-Bellany</a></span></p><div class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-wfflwi e1wtpvyy0">David Yaffe-Bellany, who covers crypto and financial technology, reported this story from Dickens County, Texas.</p></div></div></div><ul class="css-1u1psjv epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m2"><time class="css-129k401 e16638kd0" dateTime="2022-03-22T03:00:16-04:00">March 22, 2022</time></li></ul></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Along a dirt-covered road deep in Texas farm country, the cryptocurrency company Argo Blockchain is building a power plant for the internet age: a crypto “mining” site stocked with computers that generate new Bitcoins.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But unlike other Bitcoin mining operations, which consume large quantities of fossil fuels and produce carbon emissions, Argo claims it’s trying to do something environmentally responsible. As Peter Wall, Argo’s chief executive, led a tour of the 126,000-square-foot construction site one morning this month, he pointed to a row of wind turbines a few miles down the road, their white spokes shining in the sunlight.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The new facility, an hour outside Lubbock, would be fueled mostly by wind and solar energy, he declared. “This is Bitcoin mining nirvana,” Mr. Wall said. “You look off into the distance and you’ve got your renewable power.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Facing criticism from politicians and environmentalists, the cryptocurrency mining industry has embarked on a rebranding effort to challenge the prevailing view that its electricity-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate. All five of the largest publicly traded crypto mining companies say they are building or already operating plants powered by renewable energy, and industry executives have started arguing that demand from crypto miners will create opportunities for wind and solar companies to open facilities of their own.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The effort — partly a public-relations exercise, partly a genuine attempt to make the industry more sustainable — has intensified since last spring, when China began <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/24/business/china-cryptocurrency-bitcoin.html" title="">a crackdown on crypto mining</a>, forcing some mining operations to relocate to the United States. A trade group called the Bitcoin Mining Council also formed last year, partly to tackle climate issues, after Elon Musk <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1392602041025843203?lang=en" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">criticized</a> the industry for using fossil fuels.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and alt="Peter Wall, Argo’s chief executive, at the new 126,000-square-foot facility in West Texas." class="css-r3fift" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/03/18/business/00crypto-mining2/merlin_204031566_f2375c89-654d-4cfe-a9e7-332e059b2b3a-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/03/18/business/00crypto-mining2/merlin_204031566_f2375c89-654d-4cfe-a9e7-332e059b2b3a-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/03/18/business/00crypto-mining2/merlin_204031566_f2375c89-654d-4cfe-a9e7-332e059b2b3a-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="462"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Peter Wall, Argo’s chief executive, at the new 126,000-square-foot facility in West Texas.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Carter Johnston for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Crypto mining does not involve any picks or shovels. Instead, the term refers to a verification and currency creation process that is essential to the Bitcoin ecosystem. Powerful computers race one another to process transactions, solving complex mathematical problems that require quintillions of numerical guesses a second. As a reward for this authentication service, miners receive new coins, providing a financial incentive to keep the computers running.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In Bitcoin’s early years, a crypto enthusiast could mine coins by running software on a laptop. But as digital assets have become more popular, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/09/03/climate/bitcoin-carbon-footprint-electricity.html" title="">the amount of power necessary to generate Bitcoin has soared</a>. A single Bitcoin transaction now requires more than 2,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity, or enough energy to power the average American household for 73 days, researchers <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://digiconomist.net/bitcoin-energy-consumption" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">estimate</a>.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">To achieve that, some miners are <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/bitcoin-miners-are-giving-new-life-to-old-fossil-fuel-power-plants-11621594803?mod=article_inline" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">reviving broken-down coal plants</a>, or using low-cost natural gas to power their computers. Last month, a study in the journal <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/25/climate/bitcoin-china-energy-pollution.html" title="">Joule</a> found that Bitcoin mining worldwide may be responsible for about 65 megatons of carbon dioxide a year, comparable to the emissions of Greece.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">According to the study, the Bitcoin network’s use of green energy sources also dropped to an average of 25 percent in August 2021 from 42 percent in 2020. (The industry has argued that its average renewable use is closer to 60 percent.) That’s partly a result of China’s crackdown, which cut off a source of cheap hydropower. But it reflects fundamental economic incentives, too, said Alex de Vries, one of the authors of the Joule study. Renewable energy is an intermittent power source — the sun shines only part of the day, and wind speeds fluctuate considerably.</p><div id="NYT_MAIN_CONTENT_1_REGION" class="css-9tf9ac" data-testid="region"></div><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“What a miner is going to do if they want to maximize the profit is put their machine wherever it can run the entire day,” Mr. de Vries said.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-large css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:261.64444444444445px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Texas has become a hot spot for crypto mining, attracting more than two dozen companies, partly because of an unusual incentive structure with its power grid.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Carter Johnston for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Bitcoin’s ballooning energy use has long outraged environmentalists. But the criticism that made the strongest impression came from Mr. Musk, a longtime Bitcoin booster, who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1392602041025843203/photo/1" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">said</a> on Twitter in May that Tesla, his electric car company, would no longer accept cryptocurrency payments because of the “increasing use of fossil fuels for Bitcoin mining and transactions.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">His tweet sent the mining industry into crisis mode. Michael Saylor, the chief executive of the software company MicroStrategy, which invests heavily in Bitcoin, got in touch with Mr. Musk to discuss the climate issue. A group of mining executives, including Mr. Saylor and Mr. Wall, later met with Mr. Musk over Zoom.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“He wanted to make sure that the industry is on the side of sustainability, and he gave us some coaching,” Mr. Saylor recalled. “His encouragement was: ‘Find out how clean is the energy, how sustainable is the energy. Figure out how much you’re using.’” (Mr. Musk did not respond to a request for comment.)</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">After the call, Mr. Saylor set up the Bitcoin Mining Council, a forum for the industry to share ideas and coordinate environmental strategy. One member, TeraWulf, has pledged to run cryptocurrency mines using more than 90 percent zero-carbon energy. It has two projects in the works — a retired coal plant in upstate New York fueled by hydropower, and a nuclear-powered facility in Pennsylvania.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“Everyone I talk to now is talking about carbon neutrality,” said Paul Prager, the chief executive of TeraWulf. “The language has absolutely changed.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But financial priorities and technological barriers in the crypto mining industry, which includes more than a dozen publicly traded companies like Argo, are preventing a complete shift to renewable power. In late 2020, Marathon, one of the largest publicly traded mining companies, started mining Bitcoin at a coal-powered plant in Montana, citing the easy access to <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/bitcoin-miners-are-giving-new-life-to-old-fossil-fuel-power-plants-11621594803?mod=article_inline" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">cheap energy</a>.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-e1uohf e73j0it0"><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz- css-13wylk3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:290px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l6g02d ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Containers filled with dielectric coolant for the mining computers.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Carter Johnston for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz- css-13wylk3 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:290px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l6g02d ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Hoses used to run dielectric coolant to the mining computers.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Carter Johnston for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In Illinois, the cryptocurrency mining company Sangha Systems has repurposed an old steel mill in the town of Hennepin. Sangha is run by a former lawyer, Spencer Marr, who <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.sanghasystems.com/about-us" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">says</a> he founded the company to promote clean energy. But about half the Hennepin operation’s power comes from fossil fuels.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“It was a compromise we had to make,” Mr. Marr said. “It was a means to an end that allowed us to establish ourselves as a company.”</p><section role="complementary" class="css-14gh6yt" aria-label="A Guide to Cryptocurrency"><h2 class="css-ba3d02">A Guide to Cryptocurrency</h2><hr/><div id="storyline-context-container" aria-live="polite" aria-atomic="true"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Card 1 of 9</span><div data-scrolled-index="0" class="swiper css-1goft0b"><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="false"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>A glossary.<!-- --> </strong><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/03/18/technology/cryptocurrency-crypto-guide.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Cryptocurrencies</a> have gone from a curiosity to a viable investment, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/25/technology/cryptocurrency-mainstream.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">making them almost impossible to ignore</a>. If you are struggling with the terminology, let us help:</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Bitcoin.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/technology/what-is-bitcoin-price.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Bitcoin</a> is a digital token that can be sent electronically from one user to another, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin is also the name of the payment network on which this form of digital currency is stored and moved.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Blockchain.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/27/business/dealbook/blockchains-guide-information.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">blockchain</a> is a database maintained communally and that <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/06/27/business/dealbook/blockchain-currencies.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">reliably stores digital information</a>. The original blockchain was the database on which all Bitcoin transactions were stored, but non-currency-based companies and governments are also trying to use blockchain technology to store their data.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Cryptocurrencies.<!-- --> </strong><span>Since Bitcoin was <a href="https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/interactive/technology/bitcoin-timeline.html">first conceived in 2008</a>, thousands of other virtual currencies, known as <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/25/business/dealbook/bitcoin-cash-split.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">cryptocurrencies</a>, have been developed. Among them are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/technology/what-is-ethereum.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Ether</a>, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/15/style/dogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html?searchResultPosition=2&action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Dogecoin</a> and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/21/technology/bitcoin-bitfinex-tether.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">Tether</a>.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Coinbase.<!-- --> </strong><span>The first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, Coinbase is a platform that allows people and companies <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/14/business/how-did-coinbase-stock-do.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">to buy and sell various digital currencies</a>, including Bitcoin, for a transaction fee.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>DeFi.<!-- --> </strong><span>The development of cryptocurrencies spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/03/18/technology/what-is-defi-cryptocurrency.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">known as Decentralized Finance, or DeFi</a>, allowing crypto businesses to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/05/us/politics/cryptocurrency-explainer.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">move into traditional banking territory</a>, including lending and borrowing.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>NFTs.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/03/18/technology/nft-guide.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">“nonfungible token,”</a> or NFT, is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/11/arts/design/what-is-an-nft.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">an asset verified using blockchain technology</a>, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership. NFTs make <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/01/arts/design/banksy-nft-loic-gouzer-particle.html?searchResultPosition=11&action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">digital artworks</a> unique, and therefore sellable.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>Web3.<!-- --> </strong><span>The name <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/03/18/technology/web3-definition-internet.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">“web3”</a> is what some technologists call the idea of a new kind of internet service that is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/05/business/dealbook/what-is-web3.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">built using blockchain-based tokens</a>, replacing centralized, corporate platforms with open protocols and decentralized, community-run networks.</span></p></div></div><div class="css-1vt1os1" aria-hidden="true"><div class="css-kfr44l" data-testid="context-card"><p class="itemClass"><strong>DAOs.<!-- --> </strong><span>A <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/03/18/technology/what-are-daos.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-crypto-business&variant=show&region=MAIN_CONTENT_3&block=storyline_levelup_swipe_recirc">decentralized autonomous organization</a>, or DAO, is an organizational structure built with blockchain technology that is often described as a crypto co-op. DAOs form for a common purpose, like investing in start-ups, managing a stablecoin or buying NFTs.</span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="css-8r08w0"><ul class="css-1dxpste"><li class="css-cromoy" data-active="true"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li><li class="css-ku9n9i" data-active="false"></li></ul><nav aria-controls="storyline-context-container" class="css-9yx14y"><span class="arrow-left css-bfw7ir" role="button" aria-label="Previous card" aria-disabled="true" tabindex="-1"></span><span class="arrow-right css-e7hrc3" role="button" aria-label="Next card" aria-disabled="false" tabindex="0"></span></nav></div></section><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In recent months, Texas has become a hot spot for crypto mining, attracting <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/Bitcoin-mining-on-the-rise-in-Texas-with-27-16967837.php" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">more than two dozen companies</a>. The state has an unusual incentive structure that’s well suited to the nascent industry: the Texas grid operator offers what amounts to a discount to companies that can quickly unplug when electricity demand spikes statewide, allowing energy to flow to ordinary homeowners. Many crypto mines can turn on or off in seconds, allowing them to take advantage of the incentive with minimal inconvenience.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">That deal was part of the attraction for Argo, a London-based company founded in 2017 that runs two other mines in Quebec, using mostly hydropower. Mr. Wall said Argo was also drawn to the ample green energy in West Texas. The facility outside Lubbock will be connected to the western sector of the Texas energy grid, where about 85 percent of electricity comes from wind and solar infrastructure, including a set of turbines that sit practically next door to the Argo construction site.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">But Mr. Wall can’t guarantee that Argo’s new center will have no carbon footprint. That would require bypassing the grid and buying energy directly from a renewable power company.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-large css-1ef8w8q e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:306.7555555555556px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-18crmh6 ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Electrical distribution panels at the Argo facility that is under construction.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Carter Johnston for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“A lot of those renewable energy producers are still a little bit skeptical of cryptocurrency,” he said. “The crypto miners don’t have the credit profiles to sign 10- or 15-year deals.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">In the future, he said, Argo plans to build its own solar panels on site in Texas and broker deals with local renewables companies to buy energy directly.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The broader cryptocurrency community is divided over whether cleaning up the mining sector is the best path to environmental sustainability. The energy-intensive authentication system that underlies Bitcoin is known as “proof of work”; some in the industry are pushing to build new cryptocurrencies on a different system called “proof of stake,” which uses <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/12/magazine/nft-art-crypto.html" title="">as little as 0.01 percent</a> of the energy consumed in the mining process.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Wall said he had no objections to experimentation with an alternative system. Still, he said, he believes in the long-term potential of Bitcoin to transform finance, though he wishes that miners were called something that sounded less extractive, like “validators.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">That’s a battle he’s unlikely to win. But even in the face of backlash, he said, companies will keep mining Bitcoin.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“It’s just going to happen. It’s a reality,” he said. “We need to do it in an environmentally friendly way.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-2fttua"><div id="bottom-slug" a dirt-covered road deep in Texas farm country, the cryptocurrency company Argo Blockchain is building a power plant for the internet age: a crypto “mining” site stocked with computers that generate new Bitcoins.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.3.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"But unlike other Bitcoin mining operations, which consume large quantities of fossil fuels and produce carbon emissions, Argo claims it’s trying to do something environmentally responsible. As Peter Wall, Argo’s chief executive, led a tour of the 126,000-square-foot construction site one morning this month, he pointed to a row of wind turbines a few miles down the road, their white spokes shining in the sunlight.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.5.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The new facility, an hour outside Lubbock, would be fueled mostly by wind and solar energy, he declared. “This is Bitcoin mining nirvana,” Mr. Wall said. “You look off into the distance and you’ve got your renewable power.”","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.7.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Facing criticism from politicians and environmentalists, the cryptocurrency mining industry has embarked on a rebranding effort to challenge the prevailing view that its electricity-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate. All five of the largest publicly traded crypto mining companies say they are building or already operating plants powered by renewable energy, and industry executives have started arguing that demand from crypto miners will create opportunities for wind and solar companies to open facilities of their own.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.9.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The effort — partly a public-relations exercise, partly a genuine attempt to make the industry more sustainable — has intensified since last spring, when China began ","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.9.content.1":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"a crackdown on crypto mining","formats":[{"type":"id","generated":true,"id":"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.9.content.1.formats.0","typename":"LinkFormat"}]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.9.content.1.formats.0":{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F09\u002F24\u002Fbusiness\u002Fchina-cryptocurrency-bitcoin.html","title":""},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.9.content.2":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":", forcing some mining operations to relocate to the United States. mining does not involve any picks or shovels. Instead, the term refers to a verification and currency creation process that is essential to the Bitcoin ecosystem. Powerful computers race one another to process transactions, solving complex mathematical problems that require quintillions of numerical guesses a second. As a reward for this authentication service, miners receive new coins, providing a financial incentive to keep the computers running.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.15.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In Bitcoin’s early years, a crypto enthusiast could mine coins by running software on a laptop. The state has an unusual incentive structure that’s well suited to the nascent industry: the Texas grid operator offers what amounts to a discount to companies that can quickly unplug when electricity demand spikes statewide, allowing energy to flow to ordinary homeowners. href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2022\u002F03\u002F18\u002Ftechnology\u002Fcryptocurrency-crypto-guide.html\\\"\u003ECryptocurrencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have gone from a curiosity to a viable investment, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F25\u002Ftechnology\u002Fcryptocurrency-mainstream.html\\\"\u003Emaking them almost If you are struggling with the terminology, let us help:\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Bitcoin.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F01\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-bitcoin-price.html\\\"\u003EBitcoin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a digital token that can be sent electronically from one user to another, anywhere in the world. Bitcoin is also the name of the payment network on which this form of digital currency is stored and moved.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Blockchain.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2018\u002F06\u002F27\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fblockchains-guide-information.html\\\"\u003Eblockchain\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a database maintained communally and that \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2018\u002F06\u002F27\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fblockchain-currencies.html\\\"\u003Ereliably stores digital information\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The original blockchain was the database on which all Bitcoin transactions were stored, but non-currency-based companies and governments are also trying to use blockchain technology to store their data.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Cryptocurrencies.\",\"text\":\"Since Bitcoin was \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Farchive.nytimes.com\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-timeline.html\\\"\u003Efirst conceived in 2008\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, thousands of other virtual currencies, known as \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F07\u002F25\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fbitcoin-cash-split.html\\\"\u003Ecryptocurrencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, have been developed. Among them are \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F10\u002F01\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-ethereum.html\\\"\u003EEther\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F05\u002F15\u002Fstyle\u002Fdogecoin-cryptocurrency-investment.html?searchResultPosition=2\\\"\u003EDogecoin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F11\u002F21\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-bitfinex-tether.html\\\"\u003ETether\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Coinbase.\",\"text\":\"The first major cryptocurrency company to list its shares on a U.S. stock exchange, Coinbase is a platform that allows people and companies \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F14\u002Fbusiness\u002Fhow-did-coinbase-stock-do.html\\\"\u003Eto buy and sell various digital currencies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including Bitcoin, for a transaction fee.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"DeFi.\",\"text\":\"The development of cryptocurrencies spawned a parallel universe of alternative financial services, \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2022\u002F03\u002F18\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-is-defi-cryptocurrency.html\\\"\u003Eknown as Decentralized Finance, or DeFi\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, allowing crypto businesses to \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F09\u002F05\u002Fus\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcryptocurrency-explainer.html\\\"\u003Emove into traditional banking territory\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including lending and borrowing.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"NFTs.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2022\u002F03\u002F18\u002Ftechnology\u002Fnft-guide.html\\\"\u003E“nonfungible token,”\u003C\u002Fa\u003E or NFT, is \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F11\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fwhat-is-an-nft.html\\\"\u003Ean asset verified using blockchain technology\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, in which a network of computers records transactions and gives buyers proof of authenticity and ownership. NFTs make \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F01\u002Farts\u002Fdesign\u002Fbanksy-nft-loic-gouzer-particle.html?searchResultPosition=11\\\"\u003Edigital artworks\u003C\u002Fa\u003E unique, and therefore sellable.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"Web3.\",\"text\":\"The name \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2022\u002F03\u002F18\u002Ftechnology\u002Fweb3-definition-internet.html\\\"\u003E“web3”\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is what some technologists call the idea of a new kind of internet service that is \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F05\u002Fbusiness\u002Fdealbook\u002Fwhat-is-web3.html\\\"\u003Ebuilt using blockchain-based tokens\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, replacing centralized, corporate platforms with open protocols and decentralized, community-run networks.\"},{\"subtitle\":\"DAOs.\",\"text\":\"A \u003Ca href=\\\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2022\u002F03\u002F18\u002Ftechnology\u002Fwhat-are-daos.html\\\"\u003Edecentralized autonomous organization\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, or DAO, is an organizational structure built with blockchain technology that is often described as a crypto co-op. DAOs form for a common purpose, like investing in start-ups, managing a stablecoin or buying NFTs.\"}]}}]}]}","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fstoryline\u002F3ebf0054-7462-4612-9373-db6d88e097b3","tone":"FEATURE","primaryAssets":[]},"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.storylines.0":{"storyline":{"type":"id","generated":true,"id":"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.storylines.0.storyline","typename":"Storyline"},"__typename":"AssociatedStoryline","ruleName":"styln-crypto-business","testName":""},"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.associatedAssets.0":{"region":"MAIN_CONTENT_1","assetName":"email-signup-climate-fwd","ruleName":"maps-climate","testName":"","parentTest":"","asset":{"type":"id","generated":true,"id":"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.associatedAssets.0.asset","typename":"Capsule"},"__typename":"AssociatedArticleAssetBlock"},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==.associatedAssets.0.asset":{"__typename":"Capsule","uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fcapsule\u002F897f233d-3780-534a-bae7-684998acb159"},"ROOT_QUERY":{"workOrLocation({\"id\":\"\u002F2022\u002F03\u002F22\u002Ftechnology\u002Fbitcoin-miners-environment-crypto.html\"})":{"type":"id","generated":false,"id":"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzA5NzhjOWY1LTIwYzYtNTVhMy05ZDJhLWI0NzZkODk2ZmM0OQ==","typename":"Article"}}},"config":{"gqlUrlClient":"https:\u002F\u002Fsamizdat-graphql.nytimes.com\u002Fgraphql\u002Fv2","gqlRequestHeaders":{"nyt-app-type":"project-vi","nyt-app-version":"0.0.5","nyt-token":"MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEAs+\u002FoUCTBmD\u002FcLdmcecrnBMHiU\"},"gqlFetchTimeout":4000,"disablePersistedQueries":false,"fastlyHeaders":{},"initialDeviceType":"smartphone","fastlyAbraConfig":{".ver":"8964.000","HOME_chartbeat":"0_Control","INT_cwv_v2_control_split":"","INT_cwv_dfp_deferAds_0322":"","STORY_cwv_ab oembed.title: Bitcoin Miners Want to Recast Themselves as Eco-Friendly
oembed.summary: Facing intense criticism, the crypto mining industry is trying to change the view that its energy-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate.

readabilityObject.title: Bitcoin Miners Want to Recast Themselves as Eco-Friendly
readabilityObject.content:
Facing intense criticism, the crypto mining industry is trying to change the view that its energy-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate.

Wind turbines next to Argo Blockchain’s new facility in Dickens County, Texas. The site would be fueled mostly by wind and solar energy.Credit...Carter Johnston for The New York Times

David Yaffe-Bellany

David Yaffe-Bellany, who covers crypto and financial technology, reported this story from Dickens County, Texas.

  • March 22, 2022

Along a dirt-covered road deep in Texas farm country, the cryptocurrency company Argo Blockchain is building a power plant for the internet age: a crypto “mining” site stocked with computers that generate new Bitcoins.

But unlike other Bitcoin mining operations, which consume large quantities of fossil fuels and produce carbon emissions, Argo claims it’s trying to do something environmentally responsible. As Peter Wall, Argo’s chief executive, led a tour of the 126,000-square-foot construction site one morning this month, he pointed to a row of wind turbines a few miles down the road, their white spokes shining in the sunlight.

The new facility, an hour outside Lubbock, would be fueled mostly by wind and solar energy, he declared. “This is Bitcoin mining nirvana,” Mr. Wall said. “You look off into the distance and you’ve got your renewable power.”

Facing criticism from politicians and environmentalists, the cryptocurrency mining industry has embarked on a rebranding effort to challenge the prevailing view that its electricity-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate. All five of the largest publicly traded crypto mining companies say they are building or already operating plants powered by renewable energy, and industry executives have started arguing that demand from crypto miners will create opportunities for wind and solar companies to open facilities of their own.

The effort — partly a public-relations exercise, partly a genuine attempt to make the industry more sustainable — has intensified since last spring, when China began a crackdown on crypto mining, forcing some mining operations to relocate to the United States. A trade group called the Bitcoin Mining Council also formed last year, partly to tackle climate issues, after Elon Musk criticized the industry for using fossil fuels.

Crypto mining does not involve any picks or shovels. Instead, the term refers to a verification and currency creation process that is essential to the Bitcoin ecosystem. Powerful computers race one another to process transactions, solving complex mathematical problems that require quintillions of numerical guesses a second. As a reward for this authentication service, miners receive new coins, providing a financial incentive to keep the computers running.

In Bitcoin’s early years, a crypto enthusiast could mine coins by running software on a laptop. But as digital assets have become more popular, the amount of power necessary to generate Bitcoin has soared. A single Bitcoin transaction now requires more than 2,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity, or enough energy to power the average American household for 73 days, researchers estimate.

To achieve that, some miners are reviving broken-down coal plants, or using low-cost natural gas to power their computers. Last month, a study in the journal Joule found that Bitcoin mining worldwide may be responsible for about 65 megatons of carbon dioxide a year, comparable to the emissions of Greece.

According to the study, the Bitcoin network’s use of green energy sources also dropped to an average of 25 percent in August 2021 from 42 percent in 2020. (The industry has argued that its average renewable use is closer to 60 percent.) That’s partly a result of China’s crackdown, which cut off a source of cheap hydropower. But it reflects fundamental economic incentives, too, said Alex de Vries, one of the authors of the Joule study. Renewable energy is an intermittent power source — the sun shines only part of the day, and wind speeds fluctuate considerably.

“What a miner is going to do if they want to maximize the profit is put their machine wherever it can run the entire day,” Mr. de Vries said.

Bitcoin’s ballooning energy use has long outraged environmentalists. But the criticism that made the strongest impression came from Mr. Musk, a longtime Bitcoin booster, who said on Twitter in May that Tesla, his electric car company, would no longer accept cryptocurrency payments because of the “increasing use of fossil fuels for Bitcoin mining and transactions.”

His tweet sent the mining industry into crisis mode. Michael Saylor, the chief executive of the software company MicroStrategy, which invests heavily in Bitcoin, got in touch with Mr. Musk to discuss the climate issue. A group of mining executives, including Mr. Saylor and Mr. Wall, later met with Mr. Musk over Zoom.

“He wanted to make sure that the industry is on the side of sustainability, and he gave us some coaching,” Mr. Saylor recalled. “His encouragement was: ‘Find out how clean is the energy, how sustainable is the energy. Figure out how much you’re using.’” (Mr. Musk did not respond to a request for comment.)

After the call, Mr. Saylor set up the Bitcoin Mining Council, a forum for the industry to share ideas and coordinate environmental strategy. One member, TeraWulf, has pledged to run cryptocurrency mines using more than 90 percent zero-carbon energy. It has two projects in the works — a retired coal plant in upstate New York fueled by hydropower, and a nuclear-powered facility in Pennsylvania.

“Everyone I talk to now is talking about carbon neutrality,” said Paul Prager, the chief executive of TeraWulf. “The language has absolutely changed.”

But financial priorities and technological barriers in the crypto mining industry, which includes more than a dozen publicly traded companies like Argo, are preventing a complete shift to renewable power. In late 2020, Marathon, one of the largest publicly traded mining companies, started mining Bitcoin at a coal-powered plant in Montana, citing the easy access to cheap energy.

In Illinois, the cryptocurrency mining company Sangha Systems has repurposed an old steel mill in the town of Hennepin. Sangha is run by a former lawyer, Spencer Marr, who says he founded the company to promote clean energy. But about half the Hennepin operation’s power comes from fossil fuels.

“It was a compromise we had to make,” Mr. Marr said. “It was a means to an end that allowed us to establish ourselves as a company.”

In recent months, Texas has become a hot spot for crypto mining, attracting more than two dozen companies. The state has an unusual incentive structure that’s well suited to the nascent industry: the Texas grid operator offers what amounts to a discount to companies that can quickly unplug when electricity demand spikes statewide, allowing energy to flow to ordinary homeowners. Many crypto mines can turn on or off in seconds, allowing them to take advantage of the incentive with minimal inconvenience.

That deal was part of the attraction for Argo, a London-based company founded in 2017 that runs two other mines in Quebec, using mostly hydropower. Mr. Wall said Argo was also drawn to the ample green energy in West Texas. The facility outside Lubbock will be connected to the western sector of the Texas energy grid, where about 85 percent of electricity comes from wind and solar infrastructure, including a set of turbines that sit practically next door to the Argo construction site.

But Mr. Wall can’t guarantee that Argo’s new center will have no carbon footprint. That would require bypassing the grid and buying energy directly from a renewable power company.

“A lot of those renewable energy producers are still a little bit skeptical of cryptocurrency,” he said. “The crypto miners don’t have the credit profiles to sign 10- or 15-year deals.”

In the future, he said, Argo plans to build its own solar panels on site in Texas and broker deals with local renewables companies to buy energy directly.

The broader cryptocurrency community is divided over whether cleaning up the mining sector is the best path to environmental sustainability. The energy-intensive authentication system that underlies Bitcoin is known as “proof of work”; some in the industry are pushing to build new cryptocurrencies on a different system called “proof of stake,” which uses as little as 0.01 percent of the energy consumed in the mining process.

Mr. Wall said he had no objections to experimentation with an alternative system. Still, he said, he believes in the long-term potential of Bitcoin to transform finance, though he wishes that miners were called something that sounded less extractive, like “validators.”

That’s a battle he’s unlikely to win. But even in the face of backlash, he said, companies will keep mining Bitcoin.

“It’s just going to happen. It’s a reality,” he said. “We need to do it in an environmentally friendly way.”
